content.question:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

In the gas phase, <math alttext="A l C l 3 " overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>AlCl</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math> is a molecular substance. A reaction of gaseous <math alttext="A l C l 3 " overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>AlCl</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math> at high temperature is represented by the following balanced equation.

Reaction 1: <math alttext="A l C l 3, gas, reacts to produce A l, gas, plus 3 C l, gas " overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>AlCl</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>→</mo><mtext>Al</mtext><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo> </mo><mtext>Cl</mtext><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace></mpadded><mtext>Δ</mtext><msubsup><mi>H</mi><mn>1</mn><mtext>∘</mtext></msubsup><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo lspace="0.02em" rspace="0.02em">=</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>?</mo></math>

(a) How many grams of <math alttext="C l, gas" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Cl</mtext><mfenced><mi>g</mi></mfenced></math> can be formed from <math alttext="1.25 moles " overflow="scroll"> <mn>1.25</mn> <mspace width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mo> </mo> <mtext>mol</mtext> </math> of <math alttext="A l C l 3, gas" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>AlCl</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub><mfenced><mi>g</mi></mfenced></math>?

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

In the gas phase, <math alttext="A l C l 3 " overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>AlCl</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math> is a molecular substance. A reaction of gaseous <math alttext="A l C l 3 " overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>AlCl</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math> at high temperature is represented by the following balanced equation.

Reaction 1: <math alttext="A l C l 3, gas, reacts to produce A l, gas, plus 3 C l, gas " overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>AlCl</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>→</mo><mtext>Al</mtext><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo> </mo><mtext>Cl</mtext><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace></mpadded><mtext>Δ</mtext><msubsup><mi>H</mi><mn>1</mn><mtext>∘</mtext></msubsup><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo lspace="0.02em" rspace="0.02em">=</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>?</mo></math>

(a) How many grams of <math alttext="C l, gas" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Cl</mtext><mfenced><mi>g</mi></mfenced></math> can be formed from <math alttext="1.25 moles " overflow="scroll"> <mn>1.25</mn> <mspace width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mo> </mo> <mtext>mol</mtext> </math> of <math alttext="A l C l 3, gas" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>AlCl</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub><mfenced><mi>g</mi></mfenced></math>?

Additional reactions that involve <math alttext="A l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Al</mi></math> or <math alttext="C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Cl</mi></math> are shown in the following table.
Reaction Number Equation<math alttext="delta H naught sub reaction, in kilojoules per mole reaction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msubsup><mi>H</mi><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow><mtext>∘</mtext></msubsup><mo> </mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>2<math alttext="A l, solid, plus three halves C l 2, gas, reacts to produce A l C l 3, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Al</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><msub><mi>Cl</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>→</mo><msub><mi>AlCl</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math><math alttext="negative 583" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>-</mo><mn>583</mn></math>3<math alttext="A l, solid, reacts to produce A l, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Al</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>→</mo><mi>Al</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math><math alttext="positive 326" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mn>326</mn></math>4<math alttext="C l 2, gas, reacts to produce 2 C l, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Cl</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi>Cl</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math><math alttext="positive 243" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mn>243</mn></math>
(b) Calculate the value of <math alttext="delta H naught sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msubsup><mi>H</mi><mn>1</mn><mtext>∘</mtext></msubsup></math>, in <math alttext="kilojoules per mole reaction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></math>, for reaction 1 above using reactions 2, 3, and 4.

(c) A potential energy diagram for <math alttext="C l 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>Cl</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is shown in the following graph.

(i) Based on the graph, what is the bond length, in picometers, for <math alttext="C l 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>Cl</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math> ?

(ii) A student finds that the average <math alttext="A l C l single" overflow="scroll"> <mi>Al</mi> <mo>-</mo> <mi>Cl</mi> </math> bond length is <math alttext="220" overflow="scroll"><mn>220</mn></math> picometers and the average bond energy is <math alttext="425 kilojoules per mole" overflow="scroll"> <mn>425</mn> <mspace width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mtext>kJ/mol</mtext> </math>. Draw the potential energy curve for the average <math alttext="A l C l single" overflow="scroll"><mi>Al</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>Cl</mi></math> bond on the preceding graph.

(d) Three proposed Lewis diagrams for the <math alttext="A l C l 3, gas" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>AlCl</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> molecule are shown.

(i) The <math alttext="A l C l 3, gas" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>AlCl</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> molecule has a trigonal planar geometry. Which diagram (1, 2, or 3) can be eliminated based on geometry? Justify your choice based on <math alttext="V S E P R " overflow="scroll"><mtext>VSEPR</mtext></math> theory.

(ii) Which of the three diagrams is the best representation for the bonding in <math alttext="A l C l 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>AlCl</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> ? Justify your choice based on formal charges.

<math alttext="A l C l 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>AlCl</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> is known to dimerize reversibly in the gas phase. The dimerization equilibrium is represented by the following equation.
<math alttext="2 A l C l 3, gas, is in equilibrium with A l 2 C l 6, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi>AlCl</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mi>Al</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi>Cl</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>
(e) Write the expression for the equilibrium constant, <math alttext="K sub p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>p</mi></msub></math>, for this reaction.

A particle-level diagram of an equilibrium mixture of <math alttext="A l C l 3, gas" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>AlCl</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>g</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> and <math alttext="A l 2 C l 6, gas" overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>Al</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> <msub> <mn>Cl</mn> <mn>6</mn> </msub> <mpadded> <mo>(</mo> <mpadded> <mi>g</mi> </mpadded> <mo>)</mo> </mpadded> </math> at <math alttext="400 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mn>400</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo rspace="0em">°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> in a <math alttext="25 liters" overflow="scroll"><mn>25</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>L</mtext></math> closed container is shown.

(f) Using the particle-level diagram, calculate the value of <math alttext="K sub p" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>p</mi></msub></math> for the reaction if the total pressure in the container is <math alttext="22.1 atmospheres" overflow="scroll"> <mn>22.1</mn> <mspace width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mtext>atm</mtext> </math>.

skill.text: 3.A: Represent chemical phenomena using appropriate graphing techniques, including correct scale and units.
